items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Tewks. Upper Pound and Mythe Bridge river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin this morning, 26/12/21.  No further impacts are currently forecast at the Hawbridge Bridge, Sandshurst and Gloucester gauges.
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore and Severn Ham, Tewkesbury may start to fill. 
Predicted peaks:-
Upper Pound 3.1m to 3.4m and Mythe Bridge 2.9m to 3.2m are forecast Monday 27/12/21. Further showers are forecast over the next 24 hours and we expect river levels to remain high into next week. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 9am on 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Stapleford river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.  We expect flooding to affect River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue through this evening into tomorrow, 27/12/2021.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
No further rainfall is forecast tonight, 26/12/2021.  We expect river levels to remain high through to tomorrow, 27/12/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech 3.4m to 3.6m this morning, 26/12/21. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/12/21 by 09:00.

River levels have risen at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected Today.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland.   
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning 27/12/2021 by 09:00, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Coven river gauge as a result the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
The weather forecast remains unsettled and we expect levels to remain elevated in the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River Levels remain high at the Sherborne Lake river gauge and standing water on low lying land and roads may remain throughout Sunday 26/12/21. River levels are forecast to rise again in response to the forecast rainfall on Monday 27/12/21, consequently, further flooding of roads and farmland is possible during the afternoon and into the evening of Monday 27/12/21. We expect flooding to affect the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Monday morning, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

"River levels are rising at the Willington Cableway & Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this morning, 26/12/21.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Current river level at Willington river gauge is 2.26m and at Shardow river Gauge is 1.59m.  
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/12/21 or as the situation changes."

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expectedToday, 26/12/2021.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
  We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning 27/12/2021 by 09:00, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
River levels are rising at the Onibury and Ludlow (Corve) river gauges as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Sunday 26/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow. Predicted peaks:-  Onibury 1.8m to 2m this morning Sunday 26/12/21; Corve 2.3m to 2.5m this morning Sunday 26/12/21.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high today, Sunday 26/12/21.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 am on Monday 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Clay Coton river gauge following the rainfall over the last 24 hours.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated Tomorrow morning"

floodArea.riverOrSea: Marchington Brook, Picknall Brook, Rolleston Brook

items.message:
River levels are high but steadying at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington    
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to rise until later this evening.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Arrow between Studley and Salford Priors and the River Alne between Bird in Hand and Alcester on the River Alne including farmland and caravan parks.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Overnight and during Sunday, 26th December, we have seen further heavy rainfall in the Middle Nene area. This means that the River Nene and associated tributaries are now rising. Low lying land and roads close to the river may be flooded. Further rain is forecast over the next few days and we expect the river to remain high, but our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on the evening of Sunday, 26th December, or as the situation changes.
This flood alert has been removed as coastal conditions have eased and have fallen below a level of concern. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.message:
River levels have risen on the Middle River Roding as a result of heavy rainfall. River levels are expected to remain high Sunday 26 December and flooding to roads and low lying land will continue. 
We are closely monitoring the situation, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures.  
Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  this evening, 26/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook
items.message:
River levels are rising on the Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook as a result of heavy rainfall.  River levels are expected to remain high Sunday 26 December and flooding to roads and low lying land will continue. Areas most at risk are Park Lane and Colney Heath areas.   
We are closely monitoring the situation, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures.  
Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions.  You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Cheswick Green river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours. Consequently, risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow, Sunday 26/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further rainfall showers are forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this flood alert if required.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

River levels have risen at the Harford Hill river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 26/12/21 into tomorrow, 27/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Catshill to Hawford. Other areas that may be affected include Stoke Heath, Elmley Lovett, Droitwich Spa and Ombersley. 
Further rainfall showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force as river levels remain elevated after heavy rainfall on Christmas Day. River levels at Stilebridge are starting to fall this morning but further heavy showers could cause river levels to rise again at Smarden later this afternoon, 26 December. We are monitoring the situation and our incident response staff have been checking our defences and structures throughout the area. This message will be updated by 8pm this evening, Sunday 26 December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely from now into tomorrow, Monday 27th December 2021. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas along the River Mardyke between North Stifford and Purfleet.  The forecast is for further rain this afternoon and overnight to which river levels are likely to react. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update as necessary.  We will update this message by 10am Monday 27th December 2021.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely from now into tomorrow Monday 27th December 2021. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. The forecast is for further rain this afternoon and overnight to which river levels are likely to react. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update as necessary.  We will update this message by 10am on Monday 27th December 2021.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels continue to rise on the lower River Ray following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue, especially in the areas from Lower Arncott to Islip. 
Once any remaining showers have passed through the area later this morning, 26/12/2021, the rest of the day should remain dry. However, we expect river levels to remain high for the next few days at least.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded at this point. 
This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey remains in force. Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of strong onshore winds for the North Sea coast between Whitby and Filey. Overtopping waves are expected this afternoon, on Sunday 26/12/2021, between 14:30pm until 23:30pm. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Scarborough Sandside. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Sunday evening, 26/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high but steady on the River Evenlode following recent rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding remains, especially in the Evenlode area. 
Once any remaining showers have passed through the area later this morning, 26/12/2021, the rest of the day should remain dry. River levels are currently below the flood risk threshold, but may react to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing weed/trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of strong onshore winds this afternoon, on Sunday 26/12/2021 between 14:30pm and 23:30pm. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Sunday evening 26/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high but steady on the Langford Brook following recent rainfall and we expect levels to drop soon. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing. 
Once any remaining showers have passed through the area later this morning, 26/12/2021, the rest of the day should remain dry. We expect river levels to begin falling from later this morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing weed and trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Besford Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 26/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Brooks from Webheath to Defford. Other locations that may be affected include Crowle, Wickenham, Peopleton, Pinvin and Pershore. Local fords may also be flooded. 
Further rainfall showers are forecast over the next 24 hours and we expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 on 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise at the Evesham river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 26/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road. Mill Bank Road from Jubillee Bridge to Fladbury is impacted.
Predicted peaks:- Evesham 1.9m to 2.3m this afternoon, 26/12/21, Bredon 1.9 to 2.2m this evening, 26/12/21.  
Further rainfall showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force as river levels remain high after heavy rainfall on Christmas Day. Further heavy showers are expected this morning, 26 December which could cause river levels to rise again this afternoon. Minor flooding which affects low lying land and roads along the Rivers East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Whitewater Dyke, Ruckinge Dykes and the Great Stour upstream of Ashford town centre. We are monitoring the situation and our incident response staff have been checking our defences and structures throughout the area. The flood storage reservoir on the East Stour near Aldington is retaining some flood water to assist river drainage through Mersham and Ashford. This message will be updated by 8pm this evening, Sunday 26 December, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are falling and will continue to fall on Sunday 26/12/21 with a largely dry day forecast, however some standing water on low lying land and roads may remain throughout the day. River levels are forecast to rise again in response to the forecast rainfall on Monday 27/12/21, consequently, further flooding of roads and farmland is possible during the afternoon and into the evening of Monday 27/12/21. We expect flooding to affect roads around Hillfarrance, Bradford on Tone, Lane End Road at Ham and the Creech St Michael to Henlade road. Bradford on Tone ringbanks will be bankfull. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Monday morning, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling and will continue to fall on Sunday 26/12/21 with a largely dry day forecast, however some standing water on low lying land and roads may remain throughout the day. River levels are forecast to rise again in response to the forecast rainfall on Monday 27/12/21, consequently, further flooding of roads and farmland is possible during the afternoon and into the evening of Monday 27/12/21. We expect flooding to affect roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hamdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Monday morning, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The Environment Agency will continue to monitor the situation and issue any further updates as necessary.

items.message:
River levels are rising at the Newport Pagnell Cemetery river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected We expect flooding to affect River Great Ouse from Newport Pagnell to Roxton   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to continue rising.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brue, River Sheppey, North Drain, South Drain

items.message:
River levels are falling with a largely dry day forecast on Sunday, however some standing water on low lying land and roads may remain throughout the day. River levels are forecast to rise again in response to the forecast rainfall on Monday 27/12/21, consequently, further flooding of roads and farmland is possible during the afternoon and into the evening of Monday 27/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare Road.  Overtopping is forecast from the Glastonbury Millstream and the River Brue at North Drain and Westhay.  The River Brue is forecast to be bankfull upstream of Bruton Dam with field flooding likely. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Monday morning, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels continue to rise on the River Thame following recent rainfall, except in the Aylesbury area where levels are now dropping. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thame area. 
Once any remaining showers have passed through the area later this morning, 26/12/2021, the rest of the day should remain dry. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days at least.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing weed and trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid contact with flood water. 

This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett, Lower Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, River Cary, River Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but some standing water on low lying land and roads may remain. Sunday 26/12/21 will be a largely dry day, with further persistent rain forecast through Monday 27/12/21. We are not forecasting any further flooding in response to Monday’s rainfall, however we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing debris from weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.

The Western Rother is high and rising following a lot of rain (25mm) in only a few hours early Sunday morning. From 09:00 today (26/12/2021) minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads and gardens in Liss, and Mill Lane and Old Mill Lane, Sheet. From 11:00, water could also affect gardens and roads in Iping near Iping Bridge, Stedham near Stedham Lane and near North Mill in Midhurst. From 14:00 flood water will affect fields, gardens, rural roads and approach properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham and near Fittleworth Mill in Fittleworth. Rain will clear by Sunday early afternoon which should allow river levels to fall by 13:00 today in Liss and Iping. However, river levels will not fall in Fittleworth until Monday morning (27/12/2021). Another period of rain is forecast for Monday which could cause the Western Rother to rise to similar heights again, and minor flood impacts return or continue. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 on 26/12/2021.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the Upper Wey as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is possible later this morning 26/12/21, especially in the Passfield Mill area. We expect river levels to remain high. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Overnight we have seen heavy rainfall in the South Kesteven area. This means that the River Witham and associated tributaries are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river from the morning of Sunday, 26th December, onwards. Further rain is forecast over the next few days and we expect the river to remain high, but our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on the evening of Sunday, 26th December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low lying roads between Harrold and Oakley in Bedfordshire
items.message:
River levels are rising. as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.  We expect flooding to affect Roads close to the bridges at Harrold, Oakley, Felmersham and Radwell   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this evening, 26/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River East Glen, River West Glen, River Tham

items.message: Overnight we have seen heavy rainfall in the East and West Glens catchment area. This means that East and West Glens and associated tributaries are now rising, which will lead to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river from the morning of Sunday, 26th December, onwards. Further rain is forecast over the next few days and we expect the river to remain high, but our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on the evening of Sunday, 26th December, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.45 m and is stable. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 4.97 m and is stable. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m.
Pumping is taking place at Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations. Pumping at Currymoor pumping station will resume when levels in the River Tone allow.
Sunday 26/12/21 will be a largely dry day, with further persistent rain forecast through Monday 27/12/21.
The River Tone at Currymoor is forecast to remain rise as a result.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
This message will be updated Monday morning, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Due to wet weather overnight and this morning, Sunday 26th December, river levels have risen on the River Ash.
The main area of concern is currently Furneux Pelham where river levels have risen the most. There is likely to be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. 
You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
We expect the river to remain high throughout today. No flooding to properties is currently expected.
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.
This message will be updated this evening or earlier if the situation changes

The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are high and rising. 20mm of rain has been measured in 12 hours which is a lot in a short period of time. From 14:30 26/12/2021 flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and begin to approach a small number of properties in Crowhurst. Potentially including Crowhurst Recreation Ground, riverside properties on Forewood Lane and properties between the Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. Water may also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Today's rain should shortly clear to the east, leaving a largely dry Sunday afternoon. River levels in Crowhurst should begin to fall by 18:00 26/12/2021. However, more rain is forecast for Monday 27/12/2021 which could cause river levels to rise to similar heights again, and minor flood impacts return or continue. As a precaution, flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 20:00 26/12/2021

The Cuckmere River is high and rising. 20mm of rain has been measured in 12 hours, which is a lot in a short period of time. From 14:30 today (26/12/2021) minor flooding could affect fields, rural roads and approach properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly and Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm. From 16:00, minor flooding could affect Station Road, Hellingly, and approach gardens and properties on Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From the early hours of Monday (27/12/2021) minor flooding could also affect fields and rural roads in Alfriston. Today's rain should shortly clear to the east, leaving a largely dry Sunday afternoon. River levels in Hellingly should begin to fall by 22:00 today (26/12/2021). However, more rain is forecast for Monday (27/12/2021) which could cause river levels to rise to similar heights again, and minor flood impacts return or continue. The Cuckmere might not return to normal until midweek. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 26/12/2021.

River levels are rising at the Croxall river gauge consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 27/12/21 or as the situation changes.
